#Text=Niccolò dell'Abbate
#Text=Rape of Proserpine
#Text=, Louvre
#Text=Chimney breast at the Château d'Écouen
#Text=Niccolò dell'Abbate
#Text=, sometimes Nicolò and Abate ( 1509 or 1512 – 1571 ) [ 1 ] was a Mannerist Italian painter in fresco and oils .
#Text=He was of the Emilian school , and was part of the team of artists called the School of Fontainebleau that introduced the Italianate Renaissance to France .
#Text=He may be found indexed under either " Niccolò " or " Abbate " , though the former is more correct .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Niccolò dell'Abbate was born in Modena , the son of a violinist .
#Text=He trained together with Alberto Fontana in the studio of Antonio Begarelli , [ 1 ] a local Modenese sculptor ; early influences included Ferrarese painters such as Garofalo and Dosso Dossi .

#Text=He specialized in long friezes with secular and mythological subjects , including for the Palazzo dei Beccherie ( 1537 ) ; in various rooms of the Rocca di Scandiano owned by the counts Boiardo he created 12 frescoes , one for each book of The Aenid , [ 2 ] and notably a courtly ceiling Concert composed of a ring of young musicians seen in perspective , Sotto in Su ( early 1540s ) , and the Hercules Room in the Rocca Meli Lupi at Soragna ( c. 1540 – 43 ) , and possibly the loggia frescoes removed from Palazzo Casotti at Reggio Emilia .
#Text=His style was modified by exposure to Correggio and Parmigianino , [ nb 1 ] when he moved to Bologna in 1547 .
#Text=In Bologna , most of his painting depicted elaborate landscapes and aristocratic genre scenes of hunting and courtly loves , often paralleled in mythologic narratives .
#Text=It was during this time that he decorated the Palazzo Poggi , and executed a cycle of frescoes illustrating Orlando Furioso in the ducal palace at Sassuolo , near Modena .
#Text=Bologna is also the location of his illustrations for Ariosto ' s Orlando Furioso , and where he was celebrated in a sonnet which compares him to Raphael and Titian among others . [ 2 ]
#Text=One of his early pieces that cemented his reputation was the Martyrdom of St. Peter and St. Paul , in the church of the abbey of San Pietro , Modena .
#Text=He spent 1548 through 1552 in Bologna , where he gained influence from Correggio and Parmigianino .
#Text=His surviving stucco-surface landscape in the Palazzo dell'Università shows his maturing style . [ 1 ]
#Text=In 1552 , Niccolò moved to France , where he worked at the royal Château de Fontainebleau as a member of the decorating team under the direction of Francesco Primaticcio .
#Text=Within two years of his arrival he was drawing a project for a decor commemorating Anne de Montmorency ( preparatory drawing at the Louvre ) .
#Text=In Paris , he frescoed the chapel ceiling in the Hôtel de Guise ( destroyed ) , following Primaticcio 's designs .
#Text=He also executed private commissions for portable canvases of mythological subjects sited in landscapes .
#Text=He designed a series of tapestries titles Les Mois Arabesques , some of which were used by the painted enamel industry of Limoges . [ 1 ]

#Text=Much of his output reflected an often overlooked function of artists of the time : the ephemeral festive decorations erected to celebrate special occasions in the court circle , for example , the decorations for the triumphal entry into Paris staged for Charles IX and his bride Elisabeth of Austria .
#Text=His final pieces , in 1571 , were 16 murals which were done with the assistance of his son Giulio Camillo . [ 1 ]
#Text=That year , Niccolò died in Fontainebleau , France . [ 1 ]
#Text=Niccolò 's great-nephew , Ercole Abbate of Modena ( 1573-1613 ) , was one of his pupils . [ 3 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=Works

#Text=Niccolò is best known for his mythological landscape subjects , which introduced the Flemish world landscape into French art , such as the Orpheus and Landscape with the Death of Eurydice in the National Gallery , London [ 5 ] and the Rape of Prosperine in the Louvre , [ 6 ] and for his profuse and elegant drawings .
#Text=Not many of his frescoes have survived ; however the Louvre does have a collection of his drawings . [ 7 ]
#Text=Many of his canvasses were burnt in 1643 , by the Austrian regent , Anne [ 1 ]
#Text=Some of his landscapes for Charles IX were influential for the 17th century painters Claude Lorrain and Nicolas Poussin .
#Text=Footnotes
